it's kind of a waste of time and effort they're so small that that interior is
barely playable when you get a little building like this farmhouse if you were
to remove it and have the floor footprint it would be
so small it would be pointless when buildings are this small I think
you are far better off just using theater of the mind have the building on

describe what's inside or if you really really really want an interior you can
remove the building and put down one or two basic dungeon tiles to represent the

but even this is a little bit small but a house of this size is where I start to
make the interiors usable now you'll notice something when I remove this I
did not remove the roof leaving the walls all of this came off together as
one piece leaving only the footprint and in my opinion this is the most important
thing when designing playable interiors I would argue having the walls come off
with the roof is the only way to go so many people decide to have the roof
removable and leave the walls but this is chock full of problems one you're
creating double the amount of work when sculpting I did the outside i sculpted
and painted the outside at the inside is just raw styrofoam if I had the walls
remain I would have to do twice as much work for no real reason what's more
important because hey your time that's a resource you might want to spend to have
a cooler look the most important thing to me is that I don't have walls
blocking my view imagine this small footprint had walls
that were three or four inches all people sitting around the table
would have a very difficult time seeing into the building space to play with the
walls removed you have perfect eyesight from every angle
you also have the entire footprint of usable space you don't lose the size of
the walls if your walls are even 1/4 inch then you're losing half an inch on
every direction and once you start putting a bunch of objects and
miniatures inside a building like this the second you have walls in the way now
this wonderful playable interior is no longer playable because there's not
enough room you can't see and when you reach in it you're going to be really
awkward and you're gonna end up bumping some things so make the walls come off
with the roof it is so much better now what about if you have multi-story
buildings well the same principle is applied on a building like this this is
a two storey building you can remove the walls revealing the footprint of the
first floor but you can also remove the roof showing the footprint of the second
floor and you can see here I have a hole cut out for the stairwell and you can
actually see a little stairwell inside and on the main floor there is a set of
stairs so they correspond to each other in-game this is really wonderful because
you can have your building laid out on the table and then when the group enters
an area you can remove the first and second storey revealing this footprint
and place miniatures in side and put this building just beside where you're
playing now a character decides to go upstairs and explore the nice thing is
you can then remove this roof put it aside and then place that character's
mini on the second story so you have both of these
foot prints laid out side-by-side so you can show simultaneously what's happening
on the second story or the first story this is really great because when the
party is split it's a way to actually show real-time what's going on on both
floors you can take this principle and multiply it by three for however high
you want to go just keep doing this have the footprint of every floor removed
you'll notice a trend with the buildings that I have placed here they're all of a
similar size and that's because just like the small buildings where I think
